Insets a and b, and c and d, refer to samples Cu10ZA and Cu30ZA, respectively. Inset e refers to Cu10A while f and g refer to Cu30A. Insets h and i refer to sample Cu10MA. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 O2-TPO of the exhaust samples as a function of temperature. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 XRD patterns of the spent samples (top) 10 %CuO and bottom (30 %) CuO. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Ethanol TPSR over three cycles for calcined A (top) and Cu10A (bottom). The catalysts were characterized, before and after catalytic runs, by XRD, IR and UV–vis spectroscopies, SEM and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, surface area and porosity measurements. The fresh CuO-containing powders are converted into supported Cu metal catalysts in an ethanol/nitrogen stream, and act as efficient dehydrogenation catalysts producing acetaldehyde yields in the range 65–90 % at 500−650 K. The best selectivity observed on Cu/ZnAl2O4 is apparently mostly associated to the low activity of the uncovered support surface in the dehydration reactions to diethyl ether and ethylene. These catalysts are progressively deactivated already at 623 K by carbon deposition on copper sites, which leaves almost intact the activity of the uncovered support surface for dehydration reactions. This effect is easily reversed by burning in oxygen at around 650 K. Increasing copper loading only produces some increase in acetaldehyde selectivity. At higher temperature, Cu particle sintering is also observed, but it not necessarily causes evident deactivation. Keywords Copper catalysts Acetaldehyde manufacture Ethanol conversion Bioethanol Dehydrogenation Selectivity Deactivation Regeneration 1 Introduction Acetaldehyde is a main petrochemical product [1,2], used as a preservative and a flavouring agent in food engineering. It is also an important intermediate, to further produce a number of other chemicals, such as acetic acid, pyridines, ethylacetate, other acetate esters, 2-ethylhexanol, pentaerythritol, 1,3-butylene glycol, crotonaldehyde, glyoxal, etc,. Thus, it is a key chemical intermediate in the fields of cosmetic, polymer, dyes, lubricant and farmaceutical industrial chemistry. Today, acetaldehyde is mainly manufactured by ethylene oxidation in the liquid-phase Wacker-Hoechst process [3]. However, in the past it has been produced from ethanol, either by dehydrogenation or by partial oxidation [3–5]. These processes are of high interest again today, because bioethanol produced by fermentation of ligneocellulosics is expected to become a primary intermediate in the new industrial organic chemistry based on renewables [6,7]. Ethanol dehydrogenation processes were performed in the past at 533−563 K, over copper chromite catalysts with low conversion per pass (25–50 %) and recycle of the unconverted ethanol [3–5]. The final acetaldehyde yield was ca. 90 % with coproduction of several byproducts such as butyric acid, crotonaldehyde, and ethyl acetate. In addition, catalyst deactivation was occurring in industrial conditions, regeneration cycles being periodically needed. In the recent literature, several supported metal catalysts are under study for this reaction. Au- based catalysts have been investigated on different supports, i.e. SiO2 [8], mixed oxide ZnZrOx [9], ZnO and TiO2 [10]. These catalysts have high activity and selectivity at low temperature and low conversion, but deactivation due to carbon deposition has been found, more pronounced for TiO2 supported ones [10]. Recently, also Pd- based catalysts supported over ZnO have been tested in ethanol dehydrogenation at low temperature with high contact times, however low acetaldehyde yield has been achieved, i.e. 20 % approx. [11]. Supported copper catalysts (Cu-ZnO, Cu-SiO2, Cu-Al2O3, Cu-ZnO-Al2O3, Cu-Al2O3-ZrO2) are cited in technical and scientific literature for the dehydrogenation of alcohols to carbonyl compounds [12–17] and are supposed to be more ecofriendly than copper chromite catalysts [18] and cheaper than Au-based catalytic systems. Cu/graphite and Cu/graphene oxide catalysts are reported to give rise to very high selectivity to acetaldehyde (> 97 %) at conversions up to 20 % [19]. Cu-based bimetallic catalyst formulations, like Ag-Cu supported on graphite and graphene oxide, have been recently studied, but apparently the addition of Ag is not improving performances nor avoiding carbon deposition during laboratory tests [20,21]. Ni addition to Cu seems also to improve catalytic activity, but data on deactivation and regenerability are very limited [22–24]. We reported recently on the high activity of Cu/ZnAl2O4 catalysts also at high conversion, but we did not reported data on catalyst stability [25]. Thus, while catalyst deactivation and regeneration is certainly a practical point, very few data are found in the open literature concerning this subject. In this paper, we report on our studies in the conversion of ethanol over Cu-Al2O3, Cu-ZnAl2O4 and Cu-MgAl2O4 in terms of catalytic activity, deactivation and regeneration. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Catalysts have been prepared by using three different supports, i.e. zinc aluminate (Puralox Zn44, 44 wt.% ZnO, 104 m2/g), γ-Al2O3 obtained from commercial boehmite (Pural SB) and magnesium aluminate obtained from hydrotalcite (Pural Mg30). The three starting materials, all produced by Sasol, have been previously calcined at 823 K for 3 h with a ramping rate of 2 K/min. Copper was introduced by conventional wet impregnation method, using Cu(NO3)2*3H2O salt precursor in aqueous solution. The samples have been dried for 5 h at 363 K under magnetic stirring and then have been calcined in static air at 773 K for 5 h. The adopted notations for the supports are: ZA for zinc aluminate, A for calcined alumina and MA for magnesium containing one. For the final formulated catalysts, the adopted notation is: CuxZA, CuxA and CuxMA where x = 10 or 30 is the evaluated CuO loading on support basis (x = wtCuO*100/wtsupport). In Table 1 , sample notation, surface area and relevant morphological characterisation values, i.e. pore volume (Vp) and pore diameter (dp) are included. 2.2 Materials characterisation X-ray diffraction (XRD) measure for CuxZA and Cu10MA was performed on a Siemens d-500 diffractometer (CuK α radiation, Ni filter; operated in the vertical mode on 40 kV and 30 mA) equipped with the Diffract AT V3 software package. The patterns were recorded over the 2θ angle ranging from 10° to 80° at a scan rate of 1.5 degree/min. On CuxA and after catalysis samples (i.e. exhaust ones), diffraction patterns were recorded using a X’Pert powder diffractometer (CuK α radiation, Bragg Brentano geometry) in the 15 – 100° 2θ range with a step size of 0.02° and a counting time for each step of at least 15 s. On high- Cu content samples, crystallites sizes of CuO (fresh sample) and of Cu (exhaust catalyst), have been evaluated by Scherrer formula [26]. Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) surface area and porosity were measured using N2 adsorption/desorption at 77 K determined volumetrically with a Micromeritics Gemini VII 2390 V1.03 and Gemini V 2380 V1.00 instrument. All samples have been previously outgassed at 383 K for 2 h in N2. Inductively coupled plasma - optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) analysis have been performed with a plasma emission spectrometer model Ultima II - Yobin Ivon. Samples for elemental analysis were obtained by treatment of 0.1 g of sample in HNO3 + HCl + HF concentrated acid solution in a high pressure reactor. Diffuse Reflectance Ultraviolet- visible-near infrared (DR-UV–vis-NIR) spectra of both fresh and spent catalysts were collected with a JASCO V570 instrument equipped with an integrating sphere. Fourier Transform InfraRed (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Nexus ThermoNicolet instrument (OMNIC software, deuterated triglycine sulfate. DTGS, detector, 100 scans). For skeletal studies, the samples were pressed into thin wafers with KBr and spectra were recorded in air. Sample morphology was observed by means of a Scanning Electron Microscope Zeiss SUPRA 40 V P microscope, provided with a field emission gun as emitter (Field Emission Scanning Electron microscopy, FE-SEM). This instrument is equipped with a solid-state detector for backscattered electrons, with a high sensitivity “InLens” secondary electron detector and with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer OXFORD "INCA Energie 450 × 3″ for microanalysis. Sample powders were directly mounted on a high purity conductive double sided adhesive carbon tabs, and the resulting specimens were graphitised and then imaged. In the same apparatus, Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy data (EDX) are also obtained. In order to evaluate and quantify the presence of eventual carbonaceous species on the spent catalysts (tested accordingly to paragraphs 2.3.1 and 2.3.2), O2-Temperature Programmed Oxidation (O2-TPO) experiments have been performed, by feeding 170 N mL/min of an oxygen containing stream (14 % O2, N2 balanced). The test has been carried out by loading 100 mg of the spent sample in a silica glass tubular flow reactor. Temperature has been varied in between 373 K and 973 K at a ramping rate of 5 K min–1 and then it has been dwelled for 15 min. The outlet reactor gaseous stream has been continuously monitored by means of an FT-IR Instrument Nicolet 380 equipped with a home-made gas cell. CO and CO2 have been evaluated by choosing characteristic frequencies at 2170 cm−1 and 2293 cm−1 as reported in previous work of the same group [27–30]. The CO2 concentration profile is obtained as function of time (and then of temperature) in order to establish the evolution profile and evaluate the amount of carbon on the spent catalysts as wtC/ wtspent cat. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements 2.3.1 Steady state catalytic activity Catalytic experiments were performed at atmospheric pressure in a tubular flow reactor (i.d. 7 mm) using 500 mg of catalyst, 60–70 mesh sieved, thus achieving a ratio between the particle and internal reactor diameter near 25. The total flow rate has been set at 80 cc/min, corresponding to a GHSV of 10,000 h−1. The carrier gas (nitrogen) was passed through a bubbler containing ethanol (99.8 % assay, from Sigma Aldrich) maintained at constant temperature (298 K). The furnace temperature in the experiment was varied stepwise from 423 K to 773 K, product analysis was realized after 40 min to attain apparent steady state. Each catalyst has been tested for three subsequent cycles in order to evaluate catalyst deactivation preventing air exposure and allowing to shed light on deactivation. The outlet gases were analyzed after 1 h on stream by a gas chromatograph (GC) Agilent 4890 equipped with a Varian capillary column “Molsieve 5A/Porabond Q Tandem” and TCD and FID detectors in series. In order to identify the compounds of the outlet gases, a GC–MS Thermo Scientific with TG-SQC column (30 m x0.25 mm x0.25 μm) was used. Ethanol conversion is defined as usual: (1) XEtOH = (nEtOH(in) – nEtOH(out))/nEtOH(in) while selectivity to product i is defined as follows: (2) Si = ni/(νi(nEtOH(in) – nEtOH(out))) Yields are defined as follows: (3) Yi = ni / νi nEtOH(in) where ni is the moles number of compound i, and νi is the ratio of stoichiometric reaction coefficients. 2.3.2 Ethanol temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) and catalyst regeneration Innovative ways to evaluate catalysts deactivation have been developed. Cu10A catalyst has been used since it is the most prone to deactivation. The results have been compared with the one arising from the one obtained on bare alumina (calcined Pural SB, A). So, after O2-TPO three ethanol TPSR have been carried out in a silica glass reactor by setting the following parameters: 2.4 % EtOH (room T, N2 balance) with a total inlet flow rate of 170 N mL/min. The temperature is continuously raised up (373−773 K) with a ramping rate of 5 K/min, and reaction product are continuously analysed by an online FT-IR spectrophotometer with a gas cell. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Bulk and morphological characterization of fresh catalysts Analytical data on Cu content arising from ICP-OES analyses and EDX spectra acquired at low magnification, are reported and compared with the nominal composition in Table 2 . The copper loading measured by different techniques (EDXS and ICP-OES), are in good agreement with the nominal ones for ZA and MA supported catalysts. For alumina-supported catalysts the agreement between nominal Cu content values and values measured by EDX is a little worse; this may be related to the increase of the EDX error when analyzing a heavier element in a matrix of lighter ones. In all cases, XRD patterns (Fig. 1 ) of the fresh copper containing catalysts show the features of the CuO phase (tenorite, mS8, JCPDS No. 050661), whose diffraction peak intensities increase with copper content. Additionally, the supports features are also evident in the patterns, according to the relative preparation: ZnAl2O4 (spinel, JCPDS No. 05–0669) for Cu10ZA and Cu30ZA, γ-Al2O3 (nearly cubic non-stoichiometric spinel, JCPDS No. 1910345), for Cu10A (Fig. 1b) and Cu30A. In the case of Cu10MA (supported on calcined hydrotalcite), the XRD pattern shows the presence of MgAl2O4 (spinel, JCPDS No 1237057) together with a small amount of poorly crystallized γ-alumina, in agreement with literature data [31]. The average crystallite size of the CuO phase has been evaluated on 30Cu samples (Fig. 1a and 1b), by using Scherrer equation on the most intense peak (2θ = 38.78). The evaluation has been carried out by both extracting instrumental broadening and subtracting background and the outcoming results are included in Table 2. The average estimated values for CuO crystallite size are in the range of 37−42 nm. On low loading samples, the uncertainties of the evaluation are far higher than the crystallite size, thus the results were not included in the Table 2. In Fig. 2 , the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms measured at 77 K on the investigated fresh catalysts are reported. The isotherms of the CuxA and CuxZA samples are similar, both belonging to the type IV of the IUPAC classifications. The hysteresis loop shows, irrespective of Cu loading, an intermediate shape in-between H1 and H2, indicating a complex pore structure affected by network effects. Surface area (BET) decreases by increasing Cu loading from 84 to 70 m2/g without modification in the pore structure. A similar situation is observed for Cu10MA where, however, an intermediate behavior in-between H1 and H3 type isotherms is observed suggesting that the pore distribution is multimodal [32]. This is further enhanced when 10 % CuO (sample Cu10MA) is introduced in the formulation and it is in good agreement with the XRD data discussed above. By looking at the pore size distribution, in Cu10MA a family of smallest pores has a characteristic diameter of 4 nm, a second one corresponds to the curve maximum with a intermediate size (6−7 nm), while a third one might envisaged at 12 nm. The observed features are similar to those reported for the hydrotalcite support calcined at 773 K, where calcination results in the formation of new pore structure due to the removal of carbonate and hydroxide from the interlayer space. The measured surface area and pore volume values agree with those reported by Navajas et al. for Mg-Al hydrotalcites [31] (BET = 167 m2/g and a total pore volume of 0.37 cm3/g). These data indicate that Cu addition to MA introduces more smaller pores at the expenses of the second family of pores (centered at 6 nm), while almost no effect is observed on the third pore family. Correspondingly, the pore volume is reduced by 8 % upon Cu addition to MA. The FE-SEM images of the fresh calcined samples are reported in Fig. 3 . The images of the ZnAl2O4 support show irregular shapes, on which CuO phase appears in quite big polycrystalline aggregates with irregular morphology (Fig. 3a–d). Instead, on the γ-Al2O3 support, CuO crystallites form aggregates especially in the junctions between the support particles (Fig. 3e–g). Finally, the image of calcined Cu10MA (Fig. 3h, i) shows indented and wry features, where CuO phase crystallizes also in a “platelet” structure. The analysis of EDX data coupled with FE-SEM images suggest that a fixed Cu content (i.e. about 3.5 wt.% for ZA and 6 % for both MA and A, varying with the porosity and support surface area of the support) is homogeneously dispersed on the support particles, irrespective of Cu loading. Additionally, bright particles with a higher Cu concentration are also detected, whose quantity increases, by increasing the Cu amount in the catalyst. The skeletal IR spectra (Fig. 4 ) of the CuXZA agree well with that reported in literature [33,34], with three IR active fundamentals bands found at 684, 549 and 500 cm−1 assignable to the spinel ZnAl2O4, to which the spectrum of CuO (tenorite), characterized by a strong complex band in the region 600−400 cm−1, is superimposed. The skeletal spectrum of γ-Al2O3 shows two broad bands in the medium IR region at 583 cm−1 and 794 cm−1 as previously reported [35,36]. These features are found also in the spectra of samples CuxA. In the case of the spectrum of Cu30A, the feature at 583 cm−1 is shifted toward lower frequencies (540 cm−1) for the superimposition of the main absorption of tenorite. Cu10MA sample shows four bands at 791, 669, 591, 448 cm−1. In these cases, the presence of copper oxide causes an increased absorbance in the range around 500 cm−1 [37,38]. The features at 669 and 448 cm−1 evident in the spectrum of Cu10MA can be ascribed to the presence of a hydrotalcite-like phase [39], in agreement with the presence of additional stronger bands at 1345 and 1390 cm−1 due to carbonate anions. This suggests that air exposure of the prepared catalyst causes a partial re-hydration and re-carbonatation of the sample in a XRD-undetected nearly amorphous or merely superficial form. In Fig. 5 , UV–vis spectra of the investigated copper-containing samples and the respective supports are reported and compared. They show a strong absorption in the UV range near 250 and 300 nm and a broad absorption extending in the all visible region up to the NIR range, with a maximum around 700 nm. For CuxZA and Cu10MA this absorption, certainly associated to copper oxide species, being not observed in the supports spectra, shows its edge nearly coinciding with that observed in the spectrum of bulk CuO tenorite, in the range 800−1000 nm, which corresponds to the (either direct or indirect) energy gap value, in the range 1.2–1.6 eV (ca. 1050−800 nm), depending on particle size, as reported by the literature [40,41]. Thus, it seems that the visible spectrum is dominated by the absorption of CuO particles. For CuXA samples, instead, the spectrum in the vis-NIR region is different: there is a more definite and almost symmetric peak around 750 nm and the absorption tail extends more in the FIR region. This behavior was reported for similar catalysts by Marion et al. [42]. This absorption is likely due to dispersed, nearly isolated Cu2+ ions [43], and can be attributed to the three absorption bands expected for Cu2+ in tetragonally distorted octahedra, i.e., 2 A1g → 2 B1g (E1), 2 B2g → 2 B1g (E2) and 2 Eg → 2 B1g (E3) which are as always superimposed [44]. It seems likely that for CuxA samples dispersed copper ions are far more abundant than in other samples according to the larger support surface area, and their absorption dominates over that that due to CuO particles in the vis-FIR region. The absorption in the UV region near 250 nm is certainly due to O2−→Cu2+ charge transfer transitions of dispersed oxide species, although a component due to Cu+ d-d transition cannot be excluded [45]. 3.2 Catalytic performance in the ﬂow reactor 3.2.1 Catalytic materials performance in ethanol dehydrogenation The conversion of ethanol in the same or very similar conditions over the pure supports has been reported previously. While γ-Al2O3 only shows a strong dehydration activity [30], over the spinel type powders MgAl2O4 [46] and ZnAl2O4 [34] dehydration and dehydrogenation activity are both found, with the production of several compounds in particular at high temperatures. In Fig. 6 , the results of the catalytic activity over low loading samples (7.4 wt.% Cu) are summarized in terms of ethanol conversion and yield to major products. The data on catalytic activity in both the first and second cycles are included, allowing to investigate possible catalyst deactivation. The catalytic material was not pretreated prior to ethanol conversion experiment, in order to evaluate the possible conditioning on stream. By looking at ethanol conversion over the fresh catalysts (Fig. 6, first cycle), all catalysts have nearly no activity at 423 K. Cu10A is the most active already at 473 K and gives rise to increasing conversion at increasing temperature, up to complete conversion at 623 K and above. Yield to acetaldehyde increases with temperature up to a maximum value of 64 % at 573 K. At low temperature, a significant production of ethylacetate as by-product is also found (selectivity 13–17 % up to 573 K). In parallel, diethylether is also produced with increasing yield up to about 17 % and later falls down, while ethylene is also coproduced in small amounts at T ≤ 673 K,but becomes the primary product at 623 K and above (88 % yield). Thus, while at low temperature (573 K and below) the catalyst Cu10A behaves as a quite selective dehydrogenation catalyst, at high temperature it progressively converts to a dehydration catalyst. In the second cycle, the dehydrogenating activity is almost lost (acetaldehyde yield always lower than 10 %) and the catalyst behaves as a dehydration catalyst producing first diethylether and then ethylene. The dehydration activity of this catalyst is only slightly lower than that of the pure alumina support in the same conditions [30], suggesting that the copper species are almost completely deactivated and the residual support surface acts as the catalyst. Fresh Cu10ZA and Cu10MA present lower activity for ethanol conversion than Cu10A but also show a more pronounced deactivation phenomenon during the two cycles, with a decrease in conversion in the range 573−673 K, from 97 % and 90 % to 75 % and 70 %, respectively. By considering the yields to the most relevant products, these catalysts present an even higher dehydrogenation activity than Cu10A up to above 80 % yield in acetaldehyde at 573−623 K (thus with selectivities around 90 %), while a limited yield is achieved at higher temperature even though still higher than those obtained on Cu10A. In parallel, they show a lower dehydration activity than Cu10A to diethyl ether and ethylene at higher temperatures. A number of other products are observed at high temperature. In particular, over Cu10ZA an acetone yield of 24 % and a propylene yield of 15 % are obtained at 773 K. Over Cu10MA a yield above 15 % in C4 hydrocarbons is obtained at 723 K. The evaluation of the apparent activation energies at low temperature and conversion, where all the three fresh catalysts have high selectivities towards the aldehyde production (well above 90 % for Cu10ZA and Cu10MA, 100−77 % on Cu10A with coproduction of ethylacetate and diethyl ether for Cu10A), give rise to values of 104, 106 and 144 kJ/mol for fresh Cu10A, Cu10MA and Cu10ZA, respectively. These values are in rough agreement with or higher than those measured for other copper catalysts [47–49] and confirm that our experiments are realized under kinetic control. In the second cycle, also Cu10ZA and Cu10MA are less active in dehydrogenation, although over Cu10ZA acetaldehyde is still produced with a 50 % yield at 723 K. They retain only moderate dehydration activity, with the additional production of a number of compounds. (acetone, propene, ethylacetate, C4 hydrocarbons, small amounts of methane and CO2). In Fig. 7 , the results for high loading catalysts (30 % CuO) Cu30A and Cu30ZA are reported. The Mg-containing sample has been excluded due to the poor activity in dehydrogenation reaction during the second cycle evidenced for Cu10MA sample. The conversion profiles for the two catalysts are similar each other up to 623 K, and to those described above for the corresponding lower loaded catalysts. The activity of Cu30ZA is only slightly higher than that of Cu10ZA. As a result of this, acetaldehyde yield reaches 88 % at 623 K over Cu30ZA. However, again, a more marked deactivation is observed for the catalysts containing Zn during the first cycle at 623 K while full ethanol conversion is achieved on the Cu30A sample. However, also in this case, at high temperature and in the second cycle activity is mainly to dehydration products, in particular over Cu30A. The Cu30ZA sample also shows strong deactivation in the second cycle but retains remarkable dehydrogenation activity, with 56 % yield to acetaldehyde although at higher temperature, at 723 K. 3.3 Characterization of spent catalysts In order to understand the possible reason of catalysts deactivation, characterization of exhaust catalysts has been carried out by O2-TPO, FE-SEM and XRD techniques. To reveal whether carbon deposition can be at the origin of catalyst deactivation, we run O2-TPO on the exhaust samples. We measured the amount of surface carbon by integrating the CO2 evolution profile. We prefer this method with respect to the mass loss measure through TGA, since a compensative effect due to Cu oxidation to CuO might be present and not negligible in the latter case. The results are reported in Fig. 8 . We can observe that in all cases two characteristic features might be observed at two well defined temperatures, suggesting that two types of C-containing residues are formed during the reaction cycles. A low-temperature peak is detected at 560 K for all catalysts, while the higher temperature peak is more sensitive to the catalysts tested. The latter is found at 685 K for the CuXA and Cu10MA catalysts while at a significant lower temperature (640 K) for the Zn-containing catalysts. Over pure Al2O3 [30] after similar experiments, a main TPO peak is observed at about 800 K. The amount of carbon formed during the steady state experiments (Figs. 6 and 7) over the copper catalysts are summarized in terms of mgC/mgcatalyst in Table 3 . Cu10ZA and Cu30ZA are the catalysts with the lowest carbon deposition. The total amount of carbon deposited appear to actually depend on copper loading, although not linearly. The Mg-containing sample clearly shows the highest carbon deposition among 10 % Cu catalysts. The data clearly indicate that carbon deposition occurred indeed over all catalysts, and probably involves, after the full experiment up to 773 K, both copper metal particles and the support surface. It is possible to suppose that the first peak in TPO curve is associated to burning of carbon formed over copper particles, while the second peak is due to burning of carbon formed over the residual support surfaces. Copper particles likely catalyse burning of carbon species deposed on the surface support too, thus resulting in a shift of the CO2 evolution peak at lower temperature with respect to what occurs with the pure supports. In Fig. 9 , the XRD patterns of the catalysts after ethanol conversion experiments are reported. In all cases, the peaks of cubic metallic copper (Cu, cF4-Cu) are detected as the main crystalline phase, together with the peaks of the corresponding support phases. The measured particle sizes for metallic copper, evaluated with the Scherrer formula, are around 280 nm and 260 nm, for Cu30A and Cu30ZA samples, respectively. It is noteworthy that the crystal sizes of Cu metal particles after the three reaction cycles are definitely larger than the crystal sizes of the CuO particles in the fresh catalysts, suggesting that a significant sintering of the particles occurred. We may remark that in our catalytic experiments the Tammann temperature (0.5 Tmelting bulk [K]) for metallic copper (678 K) is bypassed, thus suggesting that in the high temperature steps, sintering of copper may contribute to dehydrogenation catalytic activity drop [50]. FESEM microphotographs of the exhausted catalysts are shown in Fig. 10 . Copper-containing particles are indeed grown in size, with respect to the CuO particles observed on the fresh catalyst. Additionally, copper remains also dispersed in/over the support particles, in almost the same quantity as for fresh catalysts. Moreover, it can be observed (see for instance Fig. 10b) that after dehydrogenation reaction cycles, the copper-containing aggregates (bright particles) are encapsulated in almost translucent layers, creating quite a fog, certainly constituted by light elements, i.e. carbon. 3.4 Catalysts regeneration 3.4.1 Ethanol TPSR after TPO On the alumina-based catalyst that showed the highest deactivation, i.e. 10CuA, three TPSR cycles in sequence have been carried out in conditions closed to those of the steady state experiment, after the full catalytic run (Fig. 6) and an intermediate TPO cycle. In order to evaluate deactivation, we made the same cycles also over the bare support, to have a reliable comparison in-between the two samples and to monitor the effect of the acido-basic properties and the corresponding catalytic activity of the support. In Fig. 11 top, the three ethanol TPSR over the pure alumina support are reported in terms of mol% of reactant and products. Note that the raw experimental data are given in the TPSR figures and uncertainty in the measures is higher in this case (around ± 5 %) than in steady state measurements. It is possible to detect a similar behavior to the one previously reported for the same material [28], where DEE first and ethylene later are produced with light off temperatures of 473 K and 523 K, respectively. The only detectable difference in between the three cycles is in the fact that ethylene production is even shifted toward lower temperatures (20 K, approx.) in the subsequent catalytic tests, associated to a slightly lower selectivity to diethylether production. This indicates that no significant deactivation occurs for pure alumina surface in the dehydration reactions up to 773 K in the times and conditions of our experiments. A completely different behavior is observed for 10CuA, tested after the complete experiment reported in Fig. 6, followed by a TPO cycle. During the subsequent first TPSR cycle, acetaldehyde light off is observed at 450 K. Almost 100 % production of acetaldehyde is achieved in between 573 and 673 K in this experiment. Thus, dehydrogenation activity of the catalyst, lost during the previous runs, is recovered after TPO and not significantly decreased with respect to the fresh catalyst in spite of the sintering of copper particles suggested by FE-SEM. This would indicate that a certain extent of sintering of copper particles does not necessarily causes catalyst deactivation, that is instead associated to carbon deposits formation. On the other hand, in the second TPSR cycle acetaldehyde production is much lower and the production of ethylene first and DEE later is observed (523 K) with a peak maximum for DEE at 700 K. The second and third cycles, clearly show catalysts again deactivation toward dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde that remain produced in small quantity, with dehydration product being predominant above 523 K, the light off temperature for both DEE and ethylene. At high temperature (i.e. above 723 K) ethylene is predominantly produced, together with very small amounts of acetaldehyde. We can conclude that the deactivated catalysts (during the steady state cycles) are indeed regenerated by oxidation and burning of carbon deposits during TPO, but suffer subsequent deactivation with the same characteristic cycle as the fresh one. 3.4.2 Effect of time on stream to catalytic behavior To evaluate the effect of temperature on the deactivation rate, we tested the 10CuZA catalyst at 623 K for up to 500 min on stream (Fig.12 ). At this temperature maximum acetaldehyde yield was found in the previous experiments. This temperature is lower than the Tamman temperature of copper, thus no copper sintering is expected. After few minutes, conversion is 80 % with 76 % selectivity to acetaldehyde. We observed that both conversion and selectivity to acetaldehyde slowly decline with time on stream, tending to a plateau at 60 % and 43 %, respectively, while selectivity to diethylether progressively increases from 7% t to 25 %. Also, selectivity to ethylene slightly increases with time on stream up to 9 %, while selectivity to ethylacetate is more stable at around 8 %. This experiment suggests that dehydrogenation centers deactivate progressively by carbon deposition and this results in an increasing concentration of the reactant available for the dehydration reactions to diethylether and ethylene, whose rate of formation increases. After this catalytic test, O2-TPO has been carried out in order to evaluate carbon deposition. The results are included in Fig. 13 top: a small CO2 evolution is observed, centered at around 560 K, suggesting that partial deactivation found in this experiment is due to carbon deposition on copper particles, in these conditions. The amount of carbon deposited was calculated on the basis of the amount of CO2 evolved: it corresponds to 3.0 10−3 mgC/mgcat. Considering the size of the particles calculated from XRD data, supposing all copper in the metallic state forming such nanoparticles, it seems that this value implies a significant coverage of copper metallic surface. In Fig. 13 bottom, the results of TPSR of ethanol conversion realized after this TPO run are reported. The catalyst recovered very high selective dehydrogenation activity in the range 530−650 K. Around 630 K, however, also some diethylether starts to be formed, suggesting that in this temperature range the uncovered support surface starts to catalyze dehydration, in parallel to the dehydrogenation reaction occurring on copper particles. At higher temperature, i.e. in the range 650−720 K, ethanol conversion decreases markedly, indicating that again copper deactivation occurred, while ethylene starts to become the predominant product due to dehydration over the uncovered support surface. 4 Discussion The data discussed here show that two main reactions compete upon ethanol conversion over supported copper catalysts. The dehydrogenation reaction (R1) CH3CH2OH → CH3CHO + H2 certainly occurs in contact with copper metal particle surfaces [51] although it may occur at the border between the metal particle and the support [52], and is the fastest over fresh catalysts and over catalysts regenerated by oxidation in the range 500−650 K. Previous studies showed, however, that this reaction is also catalyzed, but to a much lower extent and with much lower selectivity, by ZnAl2O4 [34] and by Mg-Al oxides [46]. Taking into account the results of catalysts characterization, it seems reasonable to suppose that CuO particles observed over the fresh catalyst rapidly reduce to Cu metal on stream already at low temperature. On the other hand, the dehydration reactions, producing diethyl ether and ethylene, occur in parallel to dehydrogenation, certainly over the support surfaces, alumina [30], Zn aluminate [34] and Mg aluminates [46]. (R2) 2CH3CH2OH → (C2H5)2O + H2O (R3) CH3CH2OH → CH2=CH2 + H2O As discussed previously [28,46], these reactions are parallel, but occurring at different temperatures. However, the production of ethylene additionally occurs with a sequence of reactions i.e. through reaction 2 followed by diethyl ether cracking, i.e. (R 4) (C2H5)2O → CH2=CH2 + CH3CH2OH Indeed, another reaction is found at low temperature, i.e. the production of ethylacetate. The formal reaction is (R 5) 2CH3CH2OH → CH3COOC2H5 + 2 H2 and is in some way successive to the production of acetaldehyde, likely with the synergy between the copper dehydrogenation sites and the support condensation sites [34,53,54]. At high temperatures, a number of other reactions occur, certainly associated to acetaldehyde overconversion, giving rise to acetone, propylene and C4 hydrocarbons. Our results show that these oxide-supported copper catalysts give rise to high selectivities to acetaldehyde not only at low conversion, as all copper based catalyst do [17,19–22], but also at very high conversion at least in our conditions, thus allowing high yields in acetaldehyde. The main factor limiting selectivity to acetaldehyde at medium temperature seems to be represented mainly by the activity of the support in dehydration reaction. However, the data indicate that the dehydrogenation reaction is quite easily deactivated over the copper particles, and this results in the formation of diethyl ether and ethylene because of more availability of the reactant reacting over the support surface. Data on deactivated catalysts provide evidence of a main phenomenon occurring on copper particles at moderate temperatures, i.e. carbon deposition. We cannot say, at this stage, what form of carbon is deposited, either adsorbed heavy molecules or coke-like species. It also seems that this catalyst poisoning effect can be quite easily reversed by reoxidation by oxygen at moderate temperature (550 K). Particle sintering does not appear to cause evident deactivation. However, more pronounced sintering may also occur after prolonged time on stream or/and at higher temperatures, as reported by other authors, producing irreversible deactivation [55]. 5 Conclusions The conclusions from the present study are the following: a) Fresh CuO/Al2O3, CuO/ZnAl2O4 and CuO/MgAl2O4 powders spontaneously convert into supported Cu metal catalysts in a stream containing ethanol in nitrogen and act as efficient dehydrogenation catalysts producing acetaldehyde yields in the range 65-90 % at 500−650 K. Acetaldehyde yields however fall at higher temperatures in all cases. b) When tested in steady state experiments up to 773 K, all these catalysts lose a large part of their dehydrogenation activity, which is recovered after burning carbon residues in TPO experiments. c) Cu/ZnAl2O4 catalyst shows slightly higher performances than Cu/Al2O3 catalysts (up to 90 % acetaldehyde yield) but suffers moderate deactivation at 623 K on stream. This deactivation effect is due to deposition of carbon species, which is easily reversed by burning in oxygen at around 550 K. d) The better selectivity in producing acetaldehyde on Cu/ZnAl2O4 with respect to Cu/γ-Al2O3 is apparently mostly associated to the lower activity of the uncovered support surface in the dehydration reactions to diethyl ether and ethylene. e) Increasing copper loading from 10 to 30 % results only in a slight increment in selectivity to acetaldehyde. This may be due to a reduced exposed support surface, reducing activity in competitive reactions, and to the different morphology and larger size of copper particles. coredata.dc:description: 10 % and 30 % wt.CuO/wtsupport CuO/Al2O3, CuO/ZnAl2O4 and CuO/MgAl2O4 were prepared through wet impregnation, starting from commercial supports (Sasol). The catalysts were characterized, before and after catalytic runs, by XRD, IR and UV–vis spectroscopies, SEM and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, surface area and porosity measurements. The fresh CuO-containing powders are converted into supported Cu metal catalysts in an ethanol/nitrogen stream, and act as efficient dehydrogenation catalysts producing acetaldehyde yields in the range 65–90 % at 500−650 K. The best selectivity observed on Cu/ZnAl2O4 is apparently mostly associated to the low activity of the uncovered support surface in the dehydration reactions to diethyl ether and ethylene. These catalysts are progressively deactivated already at 623 K by carbon deposition on copper sites, which leaves almost intact the activity of the uncovered support surface for dehydration reactions. This effect is easily reversed by burning in oxygen at around 650 K. Increasing copper loading only produces some increase in acetaldehyde selectivity. At higher temperature, Cu particle sintering is also observed, but it not necessarily causes evident deactivation.
coredata.dc:title: A study of ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde over supported copper catalysts: Catalytic activity, deactivation and regeneration
